author: gloslegofan
title: A very good small scale summary of the city
review:
Box/Instructions

The box is the usual style for Architecture - high quality and stylish. The back contains photographs of each of the real buildings depicted in the set - Berlin Wall, Reichstag, Victory Column, DB Tower, TV Tower, and the Brandenburg Gate.

The instructions are of the usual high quality for the theme. Sometimes these perfect bound annoy slightly because they tend not to stay open easily, but these instructions aren't too bad for this. A short background to each building is included in English and German, and there are a small number of facts included at various points during the build (its a shame there aren't more, which would prolong the build a little).

Parts

Fairly unremarkable, although the Dome Ø32 in transparent brown and the 10 Plate W. Bow 1X4X2/3 pieces in black were appreciated. As is custom with Architecture sets, there is a printed 'Berlin' name on a 1x8 black flat tile. The pieces of the Berlin Wall are printed with some (a little bland perhaps) grafitti/artwork.

The build

The base is built first, then the buildings are built individually from left to right, except for the mast of the TV tower which is built last. At 289 pieces the build doesn't take long, although it is enjoyable. 

The DB Tower and the TV tower are a little wobbly, but they do stay attached to the base. As this is a display set the wobble won't matter once the set is in place.

The completed model

Each building is instantly recognisable to someone who has visited the city, and the detail is impressive given the small piece count. I think the dome on the Reichstag and the curvature of the DB tower (which is of course very close to the Berlin Lego Discovery Centre!) work particularly well. It would have been nice to have more of the iconic 'golf ball' look of the real TV tower, but I realise that is impossible at this scale.

I think the size, shape and sideways facing 'Berlin' name plate work really well for building a display of cities that a AFOL has visited.

Overall opinion

This set is a very good summary of some of Berlin's most recognisable buildings, although I think it may have limited appeal for someone who has not yet visited the city compared to some of the other Architecture sets. I think the new 'cityscape' format is a brilliant idea and will produce some great low-cost sets of great cities.

author: fcoulter
title: My first Lego in over a decade - was fun
review:
I have two daughters, and while they were growing up, we'd build some Lego sets.  Sometimes we followed the instructions, while other times it was more free-form.  Apparently I didn't do a good enough job of being a father since neither of them are now engineers.

But that was a while ago, and I haven't touched Legos in a decade or so.  So I decided to start in on them again, but less for the play factor and more for the build factor.  That means I'm looking first at the Architecture theme, and then perhaps spread out.  But since I haven't done it in a while, I wasn't sure if I really wanted to do it so I started with a small set.  The Berlin skyline is one of the smaller current Architecture sets, so it seemed like a good one to start with.

Box/Instructions

The box is very study, not just thin cardboard.  Even after the set is completed, I'll probably keep the box to hold the instructions in.  And perhaps, if my daughters decide to have children, I'll end up disassembling the set and giving it to one of my (hypothetical) grandchildren.  The pictures on the box are a nice introduction to the set.

The instructions are well laid out, in perhaps too much detail.  For example, the TV tower has alternating red and white round 1x2 pieces (614121 & 614101).  Rather than just having all of the pieces placed together in a single step, it took three steps to create the alternating pieces.  While I understand the need to not do too much in a single step, this might have been a bit to fragmented.

However, I was able to build the kit without having to disassemble it and reassemble it to fix an error I made.

Parts

I don't have experience knowing which parts are rare or common.  But even with my fat and stubby fingers, I was able to handle all of the pieces without difficulty.  I do question how Lego decided which parts went in which bag; they seemed to be organized randomly.

Minifigures

It's not a minifigure, but the set comes with a very small statue for the top of the Victory Column (6138682).  Other than that, nothing that's remotely human shaped.

The build

The build is very methodical.  First you build the base, then starting with the left you build one building at a time.  This only deviates at the very end of the process, when you hold off topping off the TV Tower until after the Brandenburg Gate is completed.  The only reason that I can think of is that the TV Tower is relatively fragile, so it's possible to knock the top off while working on the Brandenburg Gate.  By waiting until after the Brandenburg Gate is finished, you're less likely to crawl around the floor looking for the top of the TV Tower.

I built it over the course of a week.  No, I'm not that slow.  But I wanted to take my time and enjoy building it.  So I built the base on day one, added the first building on day two, etc.  Some days were extremely short, but otherwise I'd end up buying another set after just one day.

The completed model

My eldest daughter traveled to Berlin (among other places) while she was in college.  She tells me that the buildings in the model look like the ones in Berlin.  I'm going to trust her on this since I haven't been to Berlin since I was a child.  But there's a nice bit of variety in the look and feel of the different buildings.  The result is a nice, variated project.

Overall opinion

This is a good project for an adult beginner.  It's not too much to handle, but the ending project doesn't look like a kid's toy.  Recommended.

For my next project, I'll be looking for something bigger.  I'll probably be building the other Skyline projects, but I'll be mixing it up a bit, too.

author: MonsterFighter
title: Looks like Berlin to me!
review:
I'm not going to write a long and detailed review as I think the construction and packaging detail has been covered in the reviews already posted, but...

Having visited Berlin for the first time last year, this seemed like a good set to get (thank you Santa).

The model captures the actual buildings well, and while I can see the disagreements about the DB tower in the reviews and comments, it is a pretty imposing structure and it certainly isn't out of place in the line up.

There is only one, very small, change that I've made to my model. I've left out the two grey technic connectors (4211483) from the TV Tower. It makes the join between the base and the tower, and the top structure and tower smoother and, in my eyes, more accurate. I'm not sure why the connectors are there as they do not 'need' to be included. 

So, having been in the dome at the Reichstag, stood next to the Victory Tower and the DB tower, had lunch in the revolving restaurant on the TV Tower, walked along the remains of the wall, and walked through the Brandenberg Gate, all I can say is well done Lego!

And if you're planning a visit to Berlin, do those things, it's a fantastic city!

Barcelona next please...
